questions.text: Which of the following statements about digoxin toxicity is false? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Hypokalemia increases the risk of digoxin toxicity.

options.label: B
options.text: The earliest manifestation of digoxin toxicity is gastrointestinal symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Serum digoxin levels always correlate with toxicity.

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperkalemia is commonly seen in advanced digoxin toxicity.

questions.correct_answer: C. Serum digoxin levels always correlate with toxicity.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serum digoxin levels always correlate with toxicity.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Serum digoxin levels do not always correlate with toxicity because of its large volume of distribution (~450L). While elevated serum levels can indicate toxicity, clinical symptoms and signs such as arrhythmias, gastrointestinal disturbances, and neurological changes may occur even at normal serum levels, particularly in individuals with altered sensitivity (e.g., hypokalemia or renal impairment).
  • • do not always correlate
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Hypokalemia increases the risk of digoxin toxicity – Hypokalemia increases the binding of digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase, thereby enhancing its toxic effects.
  • • Option A: Hypokalemia increases the risk of digoxin toxicity
  • • Option B: The earliest manifestation of digoxin toxicity is gastrointestinal symptoms – Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain are typically the earliest signs of digoxin toxicity.
  • • Option B: The earliest manifestation of digoxin toxicity is gastrointestinal symptoms
  • • Option D: Hyperkalemia is commonly seen in advanced digoxin toxicity – Hyperkalemia occurs due to Na+/K+ ATPase inhibition, leading to an inability to transport potassium into cells and its accumulation in the blood.
  • • Option D: Hyperkalemia is commonly seen in advanced digoxin toxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Digoxin toxicity can manifest with nonspecific symptoms and does not always correlate with serum levels. Understanding the interplay of electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia, and digoxin's mechanism of action is key to recognizing and managing toxicity effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has NMDA receptor antagonist activity and is also used as a bronchodilator? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ketamine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ketamine is a well-known NMDA receptor antagonist that blocks the action of glutamate, an excitatory neurotransmitter, at the NMDA receptor. This mechanism underlies its unique dissociative anesthetic effects, potent analgesia, and other applications. Additionally, ketamine is an excellent bronchodilator, making it useful in conditions like severe asthma where airway relaxation is critical.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Midazolam: Midazolam enhances the activity of GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter, and does not act on NMDA receptors or function as a bronchodilator.
  • • Option A. Midazolam:
  • • Option C. Propofol: Propofol primarily enhances GABAergic transmission and has no significant effect on NMDA receptors or bronchodilation.
  • • Option C. Propofol:
  • • Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone, a barbiturate, also acts via GABAergic mechanisms and does not antagonize NMDA receptors or serve as a bronchodilator.
  • • Option D. Thiopentone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine is a unique NMDA receptor antagonist with significant clinical applications, including dissociative anesthesia, potent analgesia, and bronchodilation. These properties make it particularly useful in pediatric anesthesia and in patients with respiratory conditions like asthma.

questions.text: Vitamin D exerts its effects by binding to which of the following classes of receptors? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: B
options.text: Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nuclear receptor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vitamin D binds to the Vitamin D Receptor (VDR) , which is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily. Like thyroid hormone receptors, VDRs are intracellular and primarily located in the nucleus. Upon binding to active Vitamin D (calcitriol), the VDR forms a complex with the retinoid X receptor (RXR) and attaches to specific DNA sequences, regulating gene transcription. This process is vital for calcium homeostasis and bone metabolism.
  • • Vitamin D Receptor (VDR)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: G protein-coupled receptor – GPCRs are involved in fast signal transduction and are not relevant to Vitamin D's mechanism of action.
  • • Option A: G protein-coupled receptor
  • • Option B: Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase – These receptors, such as the insulin receptor, mediate signaling through tyrosine phosphorylation cascades and are not involved in Vitamin D signaling.
  • • Option B: Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase
  • • Option D: Ion channel receptor – These ligand-gated ion channels facilitate rapid ion flow in response to ligand binding, unrelated to Vitamin D's genomic actions.
  • • Option D: Ion channel receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin D, like thyroid hormone, acts through nuclear receptors , emphasizing the importance of transcriptional regulation in maintaining physiological processes like calcium homeostasis and skeletal health.
  • ➤ nuclear receptors

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred for total intravenous anaesthesia in a hemodynamically unstable patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Etomidate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Etomidate is the preferred drug for induction in hemodynamically unstable patients due to its minimal impact on the cardiovascular system. It maintains hemodynamic stability by preserving cardiac output and blood pressure. These properties make it a suitable choice for total intravenous anesthesia in patients at risk of cardiovascular collapse.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ketamine: Ketamine also preserves cardiovascular stability but is more commonly used in trauma or emergency situations where dissociative anesthesia is beneficial. It is not typically the first choice for TIVA in controlled surgical settings.
  • • Option A. Ketamine:
  • • Option B. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is associated with significant cardiovascular depression and is not ideal for hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • • Option B. Thiopentone:
  • • Option C. Propofol: While propofol is the standard for TIVA due to its rapid onset and offset, it can cause significant hypotension and is not ideal for patients with cardiovascular instability.
  • • Option C. Propofol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Etomidate is the agent of choice for total intravenous anesthesia in hemodynamically unstable patients due to its cardiovascular stability. For stable patients, propofol remains the preferred agent for TIVA due to its favorable pharmacokinetics and side effect profile.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency room with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. After being administered an intravenous drug for treatment, he develops abnormal movements. Which of the following medications can be used to manage his abnormal movements? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Benzhexol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)

questions.text: A colonoscopy on an 80-year-old patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions, as shown below. He admitted to using laxatives on a regular basis. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to be the source of this problem? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Senna

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic use of stimulant laxatives like Senna can lead to melanosis coli, characterized by brownish-black pigmentation of the colonic mucosa seen on colonoscopy.

questions.text: Which intrauterine device (IUD) is associated with the lowest pregnancy rates? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ML Cu 375

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ML Cu 375 intrauterine device is known for its very low pregnancy rates, which are typically less than 1 per 100 women years. This exceptionally low rate is due to the device's efficient design and larger copper surface area, which enhances its contraceptive efficacy. The categorization of IUDs based on pregnancy rates places ML Cu 375 in the highest efficacy group.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lippe’s loop: Incorrect, as it belongs to an older generation of IUDs with generally higher pregnancy rates compared to more modern copper IUDs like the ML Cu 375.
  • • Option A. Lippe’s loop:
  • • Option B. CuT-200: Incorrect, this device also has a higher pregnancy rate than ML Cu 375, making it less effective in comparison.
  • • Option B. CuT-200:
  • • Option C. Nova-T: Incorrect, although it is an effective IUD, its pregnancy rates are still higher than those associated with ML Cu 375, placing it in a different efficacy category.
  • • Option C. Nova-T:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ML Cu 375 is the most effective intrauterine device listed in terms of preventing pregnancy, with rates less than 1 per 100 women years.

questions.text: Which of the following newly approved drugs is used in the treatment of IgA nephropathy? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sparsentan

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sparsentan is a novel dual-acting antagonist of the endothelin receptor type A and angiotensin II receptor type 1 (AT1) . It is specifically approved for the treatment of IgA nephropathy , a kidney disorder characterized by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli, leading to proteinuria and progressive kidney damage. Sparsentan reduces proteinuria and delays progression of kidney disease.
  • • endothelin receptor type A
  • • angiotensin II receptor type 1 (AT1)
  • • IgA nephropathy
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Trofinetide – Trofinetide is approved for Rett syndrome and exhibits neuroprotective properties but has no role in IgA nephropathy.
  • • Option A: Trofinetide
  • • Option B: Zavegepant – Zavegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist approved for the treatment of migraine.
  • • Option B: Zavegepant
  • • Option D: Elacestrant – Elacestrant is a selective estrogen receptor degrader (SERD) approved for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.
  • • Option D: Elacestrant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sparsentan is a new dual-action drug specifically approved for IgA nephropathy , highlighting advancements in targeted therapy for kidney diseases. Understanding its mechanism and clinical use is crucial for managing proteinuric kidney disorders.
  • ➤ IgA nephropathy

questions.text: The mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enhance fibrin degradation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) enhances fibrin degradation by converting plasminogen to plasmin, leading to the dissolution of blood clots.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Mucormycosis:
  • ➤ Treatment of Mucormycosis:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate. The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy. Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary. Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

questions.text: What is the site of action of amphotericin B in fungi? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cell membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amphotericin B targets the cell membrane of fungi by binding to ergosterol, forming pores that lead to leakage of cytoplasmic contents and fungal cell death. It is highly effective in treating severe systemic fungal infections.
